awd_titl_txt: Could Slower be better? Assessing Sintering Time, Temperature, and Area Tradeoffs in 3D Printing by Polymer Sintering
awd_abstract_narration:
3D printing (additive manufacturing) is enabling dramatic changes in design, manufacturing, and distribution. While this has created many new opportunities, the materials and the properties available with 3D printing are still much more limited than those available with traditional processes such as machining and injection molding. This award supports fundamental research to enable expansion of the range and functionality of materials used in 3D printing processes that form components by locally heating (sintering) a polymer powder (usually with a laser). As the range of available materials expands, the processes can be used more widely. The continued expansion of additive manufacturing through improved material properties, increased variety of materials, and reduced production costs, will help achieve the full benefits of additive manufacturing including low-cost customized products, faster development times, and more personalized medicine. 

Additive manufacturing via sintering of polymer powders has typically used a scanning laser to heat the materials quickly. The tightly focused laser creates large thermal gradients and short sintering times.  Relatively few materials can densify reliably without degradation under these conditions.  A single material (nylon 12) composes a large majority of all polymer-sintered components. However, a solution may be to use lower intensity light for longer time.  Build rate may be maintained or improved by heating larger areas using large laser spot sizes or by sintering an entire layer with a single exposure.  Longer processing times will require a transition from process characterization based on energy input to temperature history.  The objective of this research is to understand the effects of sintering time, temperature, and area in polymer sintering.  This will be done by modeling process outcomes based on processing temperature and time, rather than optical energy input--enabling application of viscous sintering theory to guide process development. Viscosity and sintering rates of test materials will be measured to calibrate sintering models while stiffness, strength, and viscosity measurements of heated materials will be used to identify the processing window which avoids degradation. A projection-sintering system will be developed to measure sintering outcomes (porosity, stiffness, and strength) with varying exposure time, temperature, and area.  Models will be developed to identify combinations of processing time and temperature that achieve equivalent material properties.  These models will be used to predict tradeoffs in material properties, build rate, and resolution between alternative machine architectures using point, line, and area-based heating methods. They will also accelerate selection and development of new polymer sintering materials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to understand the role that the heating time plays in the performance of additive manufacturing (i.e. 3D printing) parts made from polymer powder.  Tradition laser scanning approaches must heat each region of the powder in less than one millisecond.  This creates large thermal gradients and could potentially lead to degradation of the materials. This work studied heating times from 1 s to 20 s.

Intellectual Merit

Through the research sponsored by this award, a system was constructed that allowed for control over the heating time and temperature. Parts fabricated with this method have ductility comparable to traditional polymer parts whereas most polymer parts fabricated by additive manufacturing  are relatively brittle.  Further research showed that this was not due to the increased density but the longer times that the polymer was maintained above its melting point.  Thus, fabrication or post-processing methods that allow for more time above temperature should enhance the mechanical properties of printed parts.   Thermal imaging of these parts can be useful for detecting some types of printing defects.

Additionally, the processing method allowed time and space for optical observation. Study of optical imaging with this processing method showed that a simple optical image can predict the density and strength of the resulting parts.  The images can also be used in the process control to determine when each location in the part has been heated sufficiently for peak strength and density. 

Broader Impacts

The understanding that has been generated from these research activities has a significant opportunity to improve society. A number of patent applications have been filed and several are awarded.  A company was founded based on the printing technology and has received over $2 million in investment. Insights into the mechanisms for improving part ductility developed in this work will guide development of new manufacturing and post-processing methods that can increase the range of properties achieved and thus the number of industries that can be served by polymer additive manufacturing.  Additionally, these findings can be used to develop new methods of assuring the quality of each part that is printed. This can enable the use of additively manufactured parts in critical applications at lower costs.

Through these projects, there has been training for at least six graduate students and 15 undergraduate students.  The training that they received working on these projects has significantly enhanced their ability to contribute to the workforce after graduation.


Last Modified: 01/03/2023
Modified by: Nathan B Crane
